source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: Usually a cladding with a low $Q _ { \epsilon }$ reduction schedule will have low $f _ { n }$ while a cladding with a high $Q _ { \epsilon }$ reduction schedule will have a high $f _ { r }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: The formula for the reduction factor is defined as $\Sigma R F _ { i } = \Sigma ( Q _ { \epsilon i } \times \mathcal { I } _ { 0 } A R _ { i } )$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: a reduction factor of 45 is the result of one tube-reducing step from $6 3 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m m } \times 1 0 . 9 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ to $4 4 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m } \times 7 . 9 ~ \mathrm { m m }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk3
evidence_span: a reduction factor of 544 is the accumulation of four tube-reducing steps from $6 3 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m } \times 1 0 . 9 \ \mathrm { m m }$ to the $1 2 . 7 \ \mathrm { m m } \ \times \ 0 . 8 \ \mathrm { m m }$ final dimension.

evidence_span: A high reduction schedule that results in high $f _ { r }$ can substantially improve the corrosion resistance of $8 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ anneal material.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: zirconium-tin-niobium $( \mathbf { Z r - S n - N b } )$ alloys (iron/chromium precipitate-free) were prepared from a zirconium X-bar and subjected to corrosion test in ${ \bf 6 3 \bar { 3 } \mathrm { \bf ~ K } }$ water.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: Results showed that the corrosion resistance remarkably increased with increasing niobium content from zero up to 300 ppm and was approaching the level of VAZ alloys.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_025_chunk7
evidence_span: The materials used in this study were melted into ${ \sim } 5 \mathrm { \mathbf { k } } \mathbf { g }$ ingots. Double meltings, consisting of plasma arc and vacuum arc meltings, were conducted.
process_step: plasma arc melting, vacuum arc melting
